item.title: Footpath and Walking Environment sub-committee
item.description:
The Footpath and Walking Environment sub-committee (FPAWE)’s role is to carry forward, in Hampshire, the Ramblers charitable objectives relating to rights of way, access to the countryside and the protection and enhancement of the walking environment.

It provides:

  • Advice and guidance to the Area Council on all Footpath, access and walking environment matters in the Area
  • Co-ordinates the work of the individual Hampshire Groups by making representations on behalf of the Area Council to the highway and local planning authorities, to Ramblers Central Office and to other external bodies where appropriate

The FPAWE sub-committee has developed a range of guidance to explain how the Area’s objectives are implemented and to advise volunteers on how they should approach the tasks.

item.title: MoD Training Estate: FAQs
item.description:
1. Where does this arrangement apply?

The notification arrangement applies to all parts of the MoD Training Estate in North East Hampshire and North West Surrey where Byelaw access is permitted.

  • Managed Access Land: Most of these areas are marked on OS maps with open red triangles.
  • Range Danger Areas: Marked with solid red triangles. These are usually live-firing ranges where public access is strictly restricted.

2. What about Public Rights of Way?

Public Rights of Way (PRoW) are generally not affected by this arrangement, unless subject to “red flag” restrictions (see below).

item.description:

item.title: Area Council
item.description:
In the Ramblers, the Area serves as the vital strategic bridge between our local walking Groups, the national Central Office and our local highway authorities, currently Hampshire County Council, Portsmouth City Council and Southampton City Council.

The Role of Hampshire Area

We are one of 59 Areas across Great Britain. While local Groups focus on inspecting and maintaining paths, organising group walks or running local campaigns; the Area Council has a more strategic role. Our main functions include:

item.title: Find a walk
item.description:
When you join the Ramblers, we encourage you to join a local group. You’ll then be part of a local community of walkers and rights of way volunteers.

Find a Ramblers walk

A a group member you’ll be invited to join a mailing list to get alerts of upcoming group walks. You’ll also find a warm welcome at Ramblers group walks throughout Hampshire and, indeed, the country.You can search for walks on the national Ramblers website or app.

item.title: Volunteering
item.description:
At the Ramblers, we do everything we can to make sure everyone, everywhere can enjoy walking in nature. And our volunteers are at the very heart of this work. Together, we can achieve so much more.

Volunteering opportunities in Hampshire

There are lots of ways to volunteer in Hampshire.

  • Walk Leader for your local group
  • Donâ€™t Lose Your Way Researcher, to research, apply for, and save lost paths
  • Joining your Group or Area committee
  • Path Watcher, walking the Rights of Way in a local patch, logging and reporting any problems with signage and access to the Hampshire Countryside Service Team
  • Path clearance work, helping to keep footpaths clear and walkable

Volunteer resources

The central Ramblers website has lots of [information about volunteering[(https://www.ramblers.org.uk/support-us/volunteering), together with resources and a training library.
